title: Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears

description.text:
This derivative of Greg's Wade Extruder collects all the best ideas and latest features and improvements:
  • Greg's excellent "Guidler" for perfectly lined up filament feed AND easy access of the hobbed bolt
  • Tiltable idler-screws for opening the idler without removing the screws entirely
  • 4mm elevation of whole extruder body/bolt/motor mount to allow slightly bigger 9/47 herringbone gears
  • 2mm extra bolt-motor-distance for the same reason
  • M4 nuts and screws for idler, since M3 screws in more than 60mm length are sometimes hard to source (at least in the common hardware stores of northern germany..)
  • Well, 9/47 herringbone gears!
  • All nut-traps have been corrected for correct fit (all prusa parts seem to use slightly wrong sizes.. should be 5.5mm wrench size for M3 nuts, I changed all of them to the right ISO values with additional 0.2mm clearance. Fits great for a precisely calibrated prusa)
  • Additional hotend-mount option "reprapfaborg" for Stoffel15's great hotends that use 10mm shaft diameter of 20mm length (shown on one of the pictures as a cut-view); you can get one via http://reprap-fab.org
  • 8mm thickness of motor mount (instead of 10mm) in reference to wider herringbone gear
    • I made STL-exports for these three hotend-mounts:
  • groovemount
  • jhead mount
  • reprap-fab.org
    • My configurations were made for 0.25mm layerheight (using 0.35mm nozzle), so if you're using larger values please change the parameter in the SCAD and export your own STL. Otherwise the support-layers of bearing-hole and idler mount may not be sliced correctly. Enjoy! UPDATE 2012-03-12: As Zarquon requested via comments, I uploaded a SAE compatible version of the groovemount-extruder-body as well as the big gear. Actually I simply replaced the parameters for M3/M4/M8 nuts to the values Zarquon submitted. Please leave a comment if something still doesn't fit. UPDATE 2012-03-16:
  • Added gear-sided nut traps for GRRF hotend mount in the main wade SCAD file
  • Uploaded additional small gear STL for 4.2mm center hole diameter as requested by pharaohabq in the comments
    • UPDATE 2012-03-26:
  • Added new parameter "less_idler_bolt_dist" to adjust distance between idler and hobbed bolt, in case the idler isn't exactly vertical when tightened but slightly angled towards to hobbed bolt, which could cause the spring loaded screw to popp off the slots to the top of the idler. Default is "0", adjust for your own requirements if neccesary.

For thicker layers than 0.25mm change parameter "layer_thickness" in the "jonaskuehling_gregs_wade_v3.scad" (line 177) and export your own STL.
All hotend-mounts of Gregs latest "Guidler" version are still supported, have a look at the SCAD.
"jonaskuehling_default.scad" is my collection of useful modules like nuttrap(), polyhole(), roundcorner() etc., heavily based on prusa's, greg's and nophead's files, but modified to fit my own needs. 
Some values for M3 and M4 nuts may be hard-coded due to the lack of time. Please contact me if you'd like to suggest any change.

comments.text: This is normal and actually done on purpose. It gives the nut-traps something to sit on during the print so they are not floating in the air around the hole. It should only happen for the holes that print vertically and have the nut-trap on the bottom. DO NOT remove them from the file or you will have a mess trying to get the nuts to seat. Like you said they cut out quite easily after the print.

comments.text: Groovemount usually uses additional wooden or metallic mount sheets that are fastened together with the extruder body when mounted onto the x-carriage like the parts you see at the attached photo from the Makergear website. The top of the insulator is pushed into the extruder body while the groove stays right beneath the body so that some kind of mount piece can slide into the groove to hold the insulator in place.

comments.text: I love this version expecially for those that like to change the filament alot. However I think there is a small design flaw with the idler for this fitting? With the angle that the idler sits at when it is tight enough to hold the filament in place, the top is closer in than the bottom, so this 'encorages' the tiltable screws to want to shift up as you tighten and I fear they may pop off the idler. If the back of the idler got thicker towads the top, then this could encorage the spung tilable screws to move down when tightened and lock into place rather than up.  I hope I explained that clearly. :-E
comments.author: TechnoBill

comments.text: OK well I printed mine with a modified Idler and for me with spring loaded tiltable screws it hangs on much better now without the screws wanting ti slide off the top. I change the angle of the back of the ider by 10 degres so it was thicker at the top. That wa th bacl does not slopw in such a way they the springs want to pop off. Another solution is to pack the holes inside the idler where the bearing is held to bring it forward a bit. then the idler does not lean forward so far.
comments.author: TechnoBill

comments.text: It might be a difference in your hobbed bolt where the hobbed filament groove is slightly deeper than usual..? This would lead to a shifted filament position and therefor to an angled idler..

comments.text: There are great similarities between jhead and groovemount - both use insulators of 16mm diameter. The main differences are in the depth of the insulator-hole (groovemount is 5mm deep, jhead 10mm) and the way the hotends are fixed to the extruder. Groovemount hotends usually are just put into the hotend-mount-hole of the extruder but fixed via an additional mountplate that slides into the supplied groove of the insulator underneath the extruder. This mountplate is then tightened together with the two extruder-mount-screws onto the x carriage. The jhead style mounts don't need extra mountplates but are fixed via two screws that go right through the extruder body, passing the insulator-groove that is pushed inside the deeper mounting hole so that the insulator is hold inside.

So you ordered yourself a new Ultimaker3, cool !! now you need something to keep your PVA (or Nylon) dry as it's deteriorating super fast when left exposed.

The Ultimaker advice is to store it after use, don't leave it on the printer. My advice is store it even when printing :) .... these dual prints can take a long time.

title: Apple Watch Band Carousel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This carousel caddy was designed as a place to keep my Apple
Watch band collection. It is an improvement over my previous design wtih respect to both functionality and aesthetics. I designed using Tinkercad. I now have 4 different bands for my Apple Watch, with more to come, so I was in need of a way to store and organize them. It was inspired by my previous "Apple Watch Band Caddy" that I posted a while back but this, IMHO, is a more aesthetically pleasing and practical solution.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this Thing in PLA on a FlashForge Creator Pro using Simplify 3D with the following settings:
. resolution .2mm with .4 nozzle and extrusion width
. bed temp 60C on blue painters tape, with glass print bed (your configuration may vary).
. extruder temp 220C
. top and bottom layers 3 each, perimeter shells 2
. infill pattern full honeycomb, external fill pattern rectilinear
. print speed 80 mms
. print time about 4 hours

Assembly is simple...
  1. Attach extender pillar to base pillar
  2. Attach axel to extender pillar
  3. Slip spinner onto axel (threaded side)
  4. Screw cap onto top of spinner (spinner should rotate freely when done)

If there are any problems with the fit, sand if too tight. If the joins of the 2 pillars or the bottom of the axel are too loose they can be glued together. Do not glue the spinner or the cap to the axel as this could disable the carousel action of the spinner.

description.text:
This is an extra large version of the Advanced Delta Printer Calibration part by dolpin (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:745523). Full credit goes to dolpin for the original design, and the associated explanation. Please see his part for associated templates and procedure.

I remixed the part so that I could calibrate my Openbeam Kossel XL more accurately - this part fills the print bed up to nearer the edge, so you get a better idea of the printer performance near the edge of the bed, which is what I was having difficulty with.

Note that you will need to print out the paper calibration template in A3.

The upright parts are 80mm outside, 70mm inside (original is 60mm and 50mm).

I did not emboss the X, Y and Z in the spokes either - you can tell the part orientation because there is an additional point between the X and Y spokes.

Hope this is helpful to someone! Getting the tower angles exactly right was crucial to getting my printer calibrated.

title: Prusa i3 MK2: V2 holder clips for Y-axis' igus drylin RJZM-01-08 bushings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NOTE 2: It is to assume that the MK2s' newer and "more precise" linear shafts will induce more play in combination with the RJZM-01-08! Please ask igus via their website to provide you a free sample of the bushings and try them out before buying the remaining quantities and modifying your printer! Alternatively, use the less expensive but also excellent (if not even better) RJ4JP-01-08 bushings. You can find the corresponding clips for them here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1848700

NOTE: Project was updated on November 3rd, 2016 - Please read the project update notes below!

I upgraded my Prusa i3 MK2 with linear bushings (and shafts) from igus.

To be more specifically, the igus drylin RJZM-01-08 bushings with an aluminum shell.

Note: when you visit the igus website, you will find the product under the label RJUM-01. However, bushings for the 8 mm shaft diameter are called RJZM-01. They both belong to the same product category!

http://www.igus.eu/wpck/2292/drylin_r_rjum_01?L=en

I also had a typo in the title and the description, missing the "Z" in the name. Sorry for the confusion!

Btw.: The shafts are called AWMP-08 and are made from aluminum. Way lighter than the stainless steel shafts coming with the MK2. The bushings also glide a bit better on them, but are also very good on stainless steel - my second MK2 uses the original shafts.

Back to the summary...

Being not a big fan of the zip tie mounting principle used for the original ball bearings by Prusa Research, I designed this clips that hold the bushings in place and are screwed directly to the metal frame of the heated bed. I used M3 screws with cylindric heads, and there is no interference with the MK42 heated bad.

One big problem of the zip tie system is that the bearings wiggle around and cant against the shafts, leading to unwanted friction, noise, and vibrations. Moreover, the original Prusa i3 MK2 assembly guide says, that the two bearings, which are mounted on the same side of the Y carriage, should be as close as possible to each other. But because the notch on the carriage has rounded ends, the bearings can get askew vertically when pushed against the round endings.

My design holds the bushings centrally inside the notch, which is fine both for the travel distance of the carriage and the end-stop functionality.

Please pay attention that you use the correct clips for the proper carriage side!!!

NOTE: This clips are only suitable for the igus RJZM-01-08 drylin bearings (with aluminum shell) and NOT for the ordinary ball bearings, as the igus bearings are slightly bigger in size.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WkKJodZbx5Y

If you like to use the igus drylin RJZM-01-08 bearings also for the X-carriage (aka. the extruder), please take a look at this Thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1853471

Please also take a look at my other designs, printer parts, and tools.

If you like to support me and my work, please consider to follow me

  • here at Thingiverse
  • Twitter
  • Instagram
  • YouTube

Sending a tip over Thingiverse will buy me some coffee to stay productive. :-)
Thank you very much.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

any percentage above 0 should be okay

Notes:

Printing is easily done without any support. You can use a brim to hold the parts more securely to the bed. But if you use a brim, make sure to clean every single bit off after printing. You don't want the bearings to rest against any unintended edges.

If you experience any friction while moving the mounted bushings on a shaft it is probably due to some imperfections of the printed parts. Look closely and carefully at your printed parts and clean (cut) off any bumps.

Don't cut away the seams. They are intended to secure the bushings at their notches!

I use M3x16 Allen screws with a cylindric head to mount the clips to the frame.

Update 1:

From the lessons learned of the lm8uu bearing clips project (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1848700) if updated also the igus bearing clips to Version 2 (V2).

The changes:

  • Bearings sit now tighter inside the clips, which prevents the bearings from wiggling and rotating.
  • The clips are shorter by one layer (0.2 mm) now, which makes them snap better into the bearings' notches.
  • The M3 holes are 2.6 mm in diameter now for better screw connection
  • The clips are stronger in general

Please do not over-tighten the clips. One key for a smooth linear movement is to compensate for any imperfections by adjusting the pressure the screws put on the clips. Loosening one or both screws just a little bit can make a big difference. The clips will give you a much stiffer Y-axis than the zipties even if the screws are not tightened completely!

Update 2:

Just a small demo video at Instagram:

First the Y-carriage without the heated bed and the stepper detached. The carriage slides so easily on the shafts, that I accidentally flipped it against the axis' end. Notice that the camera is very near to the action (about 10 cm) and that even the tap of my fingernails against the metal frame seams to be very loud.

Ein von Martin Majewski (@martinjmajewski) gepostetes Video am 5. Nov 2016 um 4:33 Uhr

Second the assembled unit. This is the machine with the not dampened stepper motor.

Ein von Martin Majewski (@martinjmajewski) gepostetes Video am 5. Nov 2016 um 4:50 Uhr

Update 3:

I removed the V1 models as they seamed to have some issues.
V2 is the most current and best working version.

comments.text: Hi Martin, thank you for these! They work perfectly with PBC Linear FMC08s, which also have the 16mm OD. I just have one question. I had these pieces mounted for a while on my Y carriage, and then over the last week I was experimenting with various bearings so these came off for a bit. Later, after removing the XY frame and fixing some vertical skew on the legs (i.e. front-left and back-right legs were higher than front-right and back-left), I put the XY assembly back into the Z frame, and suddenly the holders were catching where they pass over the Z frame. After sanding off a bit of the "elephant's foot" of an overly squished first layer and reseating the XY assembly they're now clearing the Z frame, but in some places by 1mm or less. Just curious what your setup looks like with these and what kind of clearance you have. There's enough material on the overall piece that I'd feel fine sanding off a bit more to make the clearance better, I just want to ensure I haven't mounted anything incorrectly. It looks like from your pictures that this is by design. Again, thank you for the parts, my Y axis is dead silent now save for the motor!

author: HBoss

title: New Z sliding clamp for Reach3D printer

description.text:
11/20/16 edit : Front clamp updated for beter barrel diameter, and nuts inset

Based on the original hot end clamps on the Reach 3D by Nate Rogers, plus the amazing design of Benson Chan's sliding Z proximity sensor (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1695020)

This is a new all-in-one hot end clamps+Z slider + reach3D Xmin integration.
It should work with bowden E3Dv6 hot ends and chinese clones too !

The back hot end clamp is bigger than original one, you have no obligation to print that one, it's part of a bigger project of ading neopixels to the Reach3D hot end (needed to have hot end away from X gantry).
Here is the NeoPixels Holder : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1873060

Only clamp-FRONT and Z-clamp needed to work.

You will also need 2xM3 nuts, one woodscrew, and one M3x50 to slide in.

Assembly should be pretty straight forward : put the nuts in, screw the M3x50 in the nuts (let 25mm up outside), put the clamp on proximity sensor (bottom up), rotate so that the M3x50 is front of reserved hole for its head, just shove the M3x50 in place =)

Next, mount on your Reach, and manually adapt (approx) the height of the clamp on the Z prox sensor. Screw the woodscrew.

That's it. It's sliding ! Hole on top of M3x50 to fine tune your first layer !

Printer:

Reach3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15 to 20%

Notes:

For the front hot end clamp, print it upside down with supports.
Can be tricky to print... test different settings in your slicer.
Autocad Fusion 360.

title: Raspberry Pi 2 model B / 1 B+ snap-together case

description.text:
This is a subtle remix of the modular Raspberry Pi 2 Model B / 1 Model B+ case by aurelius.
The only difference is that the tabs have little snap mounts in them, which makes the top and base snap together nicely so the case won't come apart easily.
I also added a variation on the plain top part that has holes at the sides, for those concerned about ventilation.

In case you would want to adapt one of the other remixes of this case to have the same tabs:
For the top part:
Create four spheres and scale them to X,Y,Z dimensions of respectively (1.0, 1.6, 1.6) mm. Taking RaspberrySnapCase_base.stl as reference, position the spheres at (±28.5, -39.0, 11.5) mm and (±28.5, 41.47, 11.5) mm, and join them as such with the the lid when it is aligned to fit the base.
For the bottom part
Create four spheres at the same locations as above, but scale them to a size of (1.2, 1.92, 1.92) mm, then subtract them from the base.

The lid in the photo was custom made with our company logo and is not available :)

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

description.text:
The Number One Must have Free 3D print of 2016, Motor Lock For Fast Prop Install and Removal

100%EPIC has made the #1 must have 3D print for 2016. One of the biggest problems with prop swapping on your racing drone is the motor bell slipping as your turning the locknut. There are some pliers made to handle this issue but are limited to a size and can damage the motor, there are even some motors the have a special wrench that comes with then that interlocks with the top bell.

The design from 100%EPIC works like a chain strap or oil filter wrench, by using the twisting to help lock the tool in tighter without damaging the motor bell.

The new motor lock works on a wide range of motors, and is especially targeted at the FPV racers where prop swaps happen on a frequent basis. And the best part of the new motor lock is it's a FREE download. So if you or your buddy has a 3D printer, you have your project for tonight ready.

Print settings: TPU @ 205 deg 50% infill .3 Layers (fast)

Happy flying and Printing.

M150

Keep an eye on your slicer. If you make thin tweezers make sure the slicer doesn't leave gaps in the hinge. I thought that lots of perimeter shells would be a good idea, but that's how I got my gappy hinge.

Open SCAD

Just a profile in SCAD, extruded. Then I wanted a fillet, so I brought in Oskar Linde's morphology library - worked great.

title: Knob for 3/8"-20 UNC camera mount bolt
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Warning: requires lathe work to make a metal washer which is 2mm thick overall, has a 9.5mm central hole and a stepped external diameter. One step diameter is 19mm x 1mm thick and the other is 21mm x 1mm thick.

The bolt is a standard 3/8"-16 UNC that is used on larger cameras and telescopes. The ordinary camera bolt (Canon, Nikon, etc is the smaller 1/4"-20 UNC).

Camera knobs (even a cheap-o Desmond D-ring) goes for $6+. Other brand name levers, locks and knobs are very expensive. This one is for a telescope and cost at most $0.50 in materials.

I wanted to try embedding a bolt into a print, but compromised by capturing a metal washer. The knob is printed "washer-side" facing the print plate. The steel or aluminium washer is inserted just after the recess is printed, such that the metal is flush with the bottom of the knob.

Ensure that you have applied hair-spray to the washer surface before inserting, or the plastic extrusion laid on top will not stick to the washer! Also make sure you have pre-heated the washer by placing it sit on the heated bed before inserting.

The washer can't fall out, as it has a stepped edge (not 100% essential, but a nice-to-have feature). In practice, the plastic knob only exerts force onto the bolt sides. Clamping forces once the knob is tightened are 100% metal-to-metal (which is why a metal washer was used).

An objective was to make sure that zero 3D printed plastic bits were crushed when tightening up equipment using this knob.

I've not pushed the tight-fit plastic cap home for now, as I still need to machine the bolt shorter and make a slot for a retaining washer. I'll probably epoxy on the cap, then sand it flush and paint. Form Futura ABS pro sands down exceptionally smooth.

title: MKS BASE to MKS SBASE Smoothie Adapter

description.text:
So, you currently have an Arduino-based MKS-BASE V1.3 control board (or other 100x80mm board) on your hictop (or other) brand 3D printer? Does that got you down? Does 32 bit processing and 1/32 micro-stepping get you excited? Don't you wish you could just upgrade to a far superior control board, just Plun N' Play?

Now you can! -Using this awesome 100x80mm to 138.5x87mm adapter board, you can retire that old Arduino-based controller for a far superior Smoothie-based ride.

No, but really. I made this adapter board so I could put my shiny new MKS-SBASE controller in the stock place on my HICTOP-3DP11. It didn't have to look fancy (gets covered up by the control board) but I made it slightly aesthetically pleasing anyways, I mean, why not? :)

Anyways, I hope you enjoy this adapter if you need it.

Also, FWIW, I'd prefer and recommend buying a real Smoothieboard to help development on this amazing controller; the hardware and software are absolutely amazing. If these damn SBASE boards weren't so inexpensive I'd have went the other way. I am building another machine soon, and will be getting a Smoothieboard 5X. I will upload an adapter for that when the time comes.

UNLESS anyone needs an adapter for the real Smoothieboard now. Just send me the dimensions for your original mounting point, and I'll whip one up for ya!

Regards,
RidDleZ

title: Pentax Lens (PK) adaptor for 1.25" Astronomy Camera

description.text:
This adapter will allow you to connect an astronomy type camera with 1.25" nosepiece to a Pentax K mount lens.

The design is for the sensor plane of the camera to be 10mm inside the 1.25" holder, making it ideal for cameras that have a 1.25" profile throughout (ie QHY cameras) or the Altair GPCAM.

If you have a camera where the sensor cannot be placed this far within the 1.25" tube, you will need to alter the design to shorten the tube.

To get a good secure fit, also print the spacer ring which you place between the main adapter and the lens mounting plate. Having a separate spacer ring avoids the need for any supported areas in the print.

description.text:
The string represents a hyperbolic paraboloid, a type of quadric surface. Generally, hyperbolic paraboloids are defined by the equation z= y^2/a^2-x^2/b^2.  
At the center of a hyperbolic paraboloid is a saddle point. At this point the surface is both curving upwards in one direction and downwards in another.   
I designed this object by exploiting an interesting feature of hyperbolic paraboloids Ã¢ÂÂ they are doubly ruled. This means that each point has two lines passing through it that also lie on the quadric surface. The curved shape can be defined by a series of straight lines. Using string to represent these straight lines demonstrates the doubly ruled nature of hyperbolic paraboloids. I made this seemingly complex object from very simple rules.

This part was made on an Epilog Mini 18 Laser. It was vector cut out of 3mm acrylic. Both sides need to be made twice, only one base is needed. The parts were glued together with acrylic glue.  
The opening for the string is 1/10in. This left more than enough room for the string I used, however for thicker string this size may need to increase.

description.text:
This is the third, and last, file publish of my robotic arm series. This component is the arm of the robotic arm.

The following hardware will be needed to assemble the arm:

  • M3 x 8mm round head(22x), 20 used to mount the servo horns (including the gripper)
  • M3 x 10mm round head(34x)
  • M3 x 63mm round head (2x)
  • M3 x 16mm round head (4x)
  • M3 nut (2x)
  • M4 x 16mm round head(4x)
  • 8mm x 16mm x 5mm bearing, 688zz (2x)

The following electronic parts will be needed:

  • Standard size servo (5x), e.g. TowerPro MG995

The assembly should be pretty straight forward, just follow the exploded view. Questions?? Message me!

Notes:

  • Print the base servo mount, bearing holder, center arm bearing guide, center arm bearing guide clamp and the lower arm bushing twice.
  • All critical holes are oversized by 0.25mm to guarantee an easy fit.
    All the M3 / M4 holes are sized 2.8mm / 3.8mm in diameter. Apply some grease (not necessary, but it makes it easier) on a normal bolt and screw them in the parts with some proper tools. This should make some neat and tight threads in the plastic.
  • This design is not fully tested, so it might undergo some changes in the future.
  • It's best to put support in round shaped overhangs, for example you should place the center arm with the circular indent face down on your print bed and then add supports. After printing you can grind down any residue of support material with a dremel tool or something similar.

Printer:

Craftbot Plus

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15% - 25%

description.text:
Here is a 15 degree mount for the New FPV Inductrix. This allows you to tilt the camera while retaining the stock appearance and canopy protection.

A slightly modified version is available from AmainHobbies.com for those that want to purchase vs print/have printed. I highly suggest trying their Protek batteries as well.

100%

Notes:

This little part has alot of thin profiles. It prints fine in PLA or ABS at 10 or even 20 microns with a 0.4mm nozzle. Smaller would definitely be better.

Supports are required to build the offset it has to allow the VTX to mount like it did before. I ran mine in lines at 1mm spacing, with a perimeter. Use a sharp razor to remove them.

comments.text: Prints and fits perfect.  I can fly much faster with my inductrix fpv.  Weight gain in nominal.  If you are frustrated with not getting the view you need when racing your whoop, give this a try for sure.

title: Parts list for Martian rover build

description.text:
This is the parts list for the Martian Rover that I built (http://www.thingiverse.com/make:222381). Thingiverse won't let me upload this parts list file as part of the "Make" that I did because (it seems that) a "Make" can only include image files.

This is the list of passive mechanical parts only. You may want to use a few more washers...

You will also need electrical wire, glue, etc. as well as all the motors, active electronics and special parts (e.g. suspension) as listed in RepBaza's original thing (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1318414).

description.text:
This adapter couples a 2 1/2" power tool vacuum output to a 1 1/4" vacuum hose.

If you need a more durable part or your thin walls are prone to delamination, consider my Industrial Vacuum Adapter 2 1/2" to 1 1/4".

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Optimized for 0.40 mm nozzles. Wall thickness is 1.6 mm so it has 4 shells on most layers. That keeps the print head moving in smooth circles.

For this application I prefer the flexibility of ABS. If you print in PLA, try scaling to about 99.5%. Save some filament by printing the test file first. It is the top and bottom 2 mm of the adapter.

Also, consider adding a skirt of 8-10 perimeters touching the part so it won't lift off the print bed.

Scrape the bottom edges smooth with a hobby knife.

Acetone vapor bath for strength is optional.

title: e3d V6 carriage mount for duplicator / ctc

description.text:
e3d V6 carriage mount for duplicator / ctc.

I am using this and it works really well.
Because the motor & drive block is not sitting behind the heatsink it stays cooler,
I had to keep replacing the spring loaded drive block arms as they kept warping over time and loosing tension on the filament.
Changing filament is easier also as you can see what your doing too. No more broken fan blades, no more dismantling the fan to get to the motor, happy days!

update
adder v2, slight alteration to design. added a lip to stop bushes coming loose.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.19

Infill:

100

Notes:

please note the hot end drops quite low below the carriage approx 15mm so print bed will need adjusting quite a bit. (I made it this way as I use sequential printing quite a bit and i needed at least 15mm clearance)

description.text: I was having issues with my Solidoodle 4 locking up. Long and short of the story, my Solidoodle 4 is now a Frankendoodle 4 (see my other posts). I added a headed bed that was 200w and needed a bigger power supply than the XBOX type what was attached. I found a 33A/360W one on eBay; however, my OCD got the better of me and I designed a case to cover the power supply and added a switch. It was getting old to "pull the plug" to turn off the printer.

title: Hictop Prusa i3 3dp-18 Y End Stop Switch Mount

description.text:
This is my take on a Y axis end point switch mount. The original mounting location on the hictop 3d printers is under the bed. After time, the solder joints break on the micro switch due to the continual movement.

This attaches directly to the y axis motor mount via the top two bolts (you will need to replace the two bolts with slightly longer ones), then the switch attaches to the mount. This will eliminate the wires breaking as there is no longer any movement.

There are similar mounts on here, but they did not work on my printer. This should be universal for most hictop 3d printers.

This fan duct will allow you to upgrade your cooling fan easily to a 12V DC 50mm Blow Radial Cooling Fan.

https://www.amazon.com/Connector-Cooling-Blower-50mmx15mm-uxcell/dp/B00MJU6JR2/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1476920027&sr=1-1-fkmr0&keywords=2V+DC+50mm+Blow+Radial+Cooling+Fan

A M4x20 screw (or longer) is used to hold the new fan in.

PID HEAT MANAGER- use for best hotend performance
This describes how to make your Duplicator i3 use PID heat management for best temperature control of the hotend, no matter which cooler you use.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ki-JOwre82Y

Edit 11/13/16

Added a fan duct to upgrade from a 40mm fan.

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1726127

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1726127

Assembly/Print Settings

To assemble the GO Case, print the lid and aimer both flat.

The case pieces both print upright, and are made to simply snap together! This friction fit joint works well with ABS filament, but may not work as well with PLA. For a firm connection, you can use a hammer on the edges to join the two pieces. You can also add a little glue if you want it to really be super snug.

The hinges are a print-in-place model (use ABS filament for the hinge, PLA seems to work poorly for pins in our experience), and can be printed in one piece! The button latch slides down and acts as a lock, to keep the lid securely shut when the case is in your backpack or pocket! Place the Lock Pin, long side down, in the insert in the Case Top, and glue the Button to the protruding piece of the Lock Pin.

Once everything is printed, glue some 1/4" x 1/16" magnets into the voids in the case, which will allow it to snap shut when closed. Some super glue in the hole will keep the magnets securely in place.

Snap the hinges into the lid and the combined case pieces, and snap the aimer into the case. That's it! Now you're ready to GO!

title: Improved X ends for Prusa with clamped rods

description.text:
I liked the idea of older Prusa x ends, that use two screws for each rod to fix it, but the implementation was rather weak. With iteration 2's solution (press fit, closed ends) it's a mess to disassemble the x axis, so I thought up a new robust version and since modifying one of the existing files would have taken even more time, I designed it from sratch and added even more upgrades like my clamped LM8UU holders!
Prusa's snap in LM8UU holders have one huge problem: motor- and idler-mount are supported via those holders, so the whole holder can twist unevenly and warp the bearings agains each other. This is avoided with my design.
The rods are fixed using one screw for each, tightening the built in clamps. Their screw heads are easily accessible from below and there are nut traps at the top. I made open end rod holes, to be able to push the rods all through. The system achieves a rock solid fit AND easy adjustability - what else you should need?
The leadscrew nut trap uses two bridges inside instead of a circular hole, so there's no "post-print-processing" (i.e. drilling) necessary in this point.
The design is entirely parametric, so you can even use professional leadscrews like trapezoidal ones with bigger nuts. I additionally attached STLs for use with metric trapezoidal leadscrews TR8x1.5 and nuts of 17mm wrench size (15mm height). For standard Prusa requirements use the "threaded rod" files.

There are thin support layers inside the M3 rod clamp holes that need to be drilled through after printing!
The STLs are generated for 0.25mm layer height - change the parameter in OpenSCAD for your needs.

title: White keys for the Arturis MiniLab
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I bought a used Arturis MiniLab MIDI controller. It was pretty cheap, since it had broken keys (which I thought would be an easy fix). I can (and probably will) just repair the keys it came with, but for fun I decided to model them in SketchUp.

The model is too big for my printer's bed, and I haven't decided how I want to break it up into two pieces, so I haven't printed any, yet. I originally thought I might be able to slice it into layers, use a laser-cutter to cut the layers out of acrylic, and make them that way. A set made using an SLS printer would be nice, but it would probably cost more than just buying a brand-new MiniLab...

If you need this, you already know that the MiniLab needs two of the seven-key sets, plus one extra C key (the 25th key, counting all keys from the left), plus the black keys (which I haven't modeled, since mine are still intact).

Let me know if you want the black keys modeled (especially if you'd like to show your appreciation by printing/machining a couple of sets of white ones for me ;)

description.text: This is a Thor Costume that I have designed myself. I am a 14 year old in 9th grade that just got involved in 3d designing and printing. I have been working on this for 15 days and have been learning from scratch ever since. I have learned the whole software by myself within the duration of this project. My school provided the filament and 3d printer needed to make this costume. I made a full Thor Armor piece and a twelve piece split Thor Armor set to put together. You need to glue the Thor Armor together if you print the pieces of the split Thor Armor. Also, before you print, you need to adjust the pieces to the size of your body. You can use whatever filament suits you.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Twelve piece split Thor Armor set needs to be glued together.

Be Careful

Be careful when taking off the raft and supports.

How I Designed my Costume

I designed my costume by starting from scratch, but I had an amazing dream of what it would end up to be. My project has taught me not only to design 3d objects, but how to learn on my own. This is an awesome field that I hope I can continue to explore and strive at.
NGSS

About My Costume My costume took a lot of time and effort to design/print. I started this project 15 days ago, and worked about 3 hours each day on it. By doing this I have learned to design a costume that not only looks cool, but was very complicated to design. I am very grateful to be given this opportunity to strive in the field of 3d designing and can't wait to design another cool thing like this one.

What I did to Accomplish This Costume My plan was to make a costume that amazed people. When I thought of a superhero costume, I was hooked. Thor is one of my favorite superheroes with a costume that I could make. I had a dream of what my costume could turn out like and it turned out perfect. My activity of this costume was very short, but precise. For a first time designer, I'd say it's pretty good.
Filament and 3d Printer You need any filament color you prefer and a compatible 3d printer that can print my costume.

• 3d designing
  • 3d printing
15 days
My School Thank you for providing the materials I needed to design this costume

title: PVC End Caps for Air Piston

description.text:
Description

End caps for 1" PVC and 3/4" PVC pipe to make a triple nest air piston. 1" to 3/4" to 1/2". Used for a Halloween themed pop-up-from-behind-the-bushes prop.

How to Print

Printed in PLA scaled to 102.20% on a Monoprice Architect printer.

The Grand Scheme

See video. The inner-bottom of each section of pipe was heated with a heat gun and squished together to form a slight bulge to prevent the pipe from existing the cap. Filed and sanded for a more precise fit to slide/collapse nicely. I couldn't get normal PVC caps to work without the PVC wedging...preventing the collapse. Used normal PVC cement with a heavy dose of primer. Unsure of durability of joint at this point.

Things to Buy

https://www.sprinklerwarehouse.com/ProductDetails.asp?ProductCode=100-HV-NPT

Each riser function allows for adjustments of the following:

-Riser Variance

description.text:
Wanted a retro TV for RetroPie for Adafruit's HDMI 5" backpack (product ID 2260). The body is printed in light cherry Laywoo-D3 filament (Accidentally printed at different temperatures for each half, which is why it's so obviously printed in two halves).

It also requires a separate analog (3.5mm) input, as the HDMI screen does not have audio.

Remixed this to fit and added screw mounts. I've also put a back panel with passthrough connections. The bottom dial is a push button on/off switch. I could use an LED indicator for the PowerBoost in future versions.

I've also put in an Adafruit PowerBoost Charger and Li-Ion battery so I can run it on battery power. There's also a port in the back to run a Pi off of the battery as well.

PARTS:

Adafruit HDMI 5" Display Backpack - With Touch (can substitute for the one without touch )

Adafruit Powerboost 1000

6600 mAh Lithium-Ion Battery Pack

USB hub to split the power

Tactile On-Off Switch

X-Mini UNO speaker

HDMI right-angle adapter

Panel adapters:

Micro-USB to Micro-USB for charging the battery
USB-A to USB-A for the external powered USB port for the Raspberry Pi
HDMI
Audio

MISC:
2 short micro-USB cables to power the display and speaker, a short 3.5mm patch cable to connect the panel 3.5mm jack with the speaker.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Should print without supports. Parts are huge, so the frame is split, and may need a raft to prevent curling.

These were designed to print without supports- as long as it's in the orientation shown in the picture above

This was designed for a friend, he is doing commission printing, assembly, painting, and finishing. If you are interested, please contact him at [email protected]

Parts Needed

Printed
1x Underside_Ring.stl
1x Small Ring.stl
1x Main Body.stl
1x Bottom Cap.stl
1x Hammer.stl
Other
1x 3/4" Dowel @ 50mm
1x 3/4" Dowel @ 60mm
1x 3/4" Rod/Dowel @ 24" (2') May vary dependent on user, choose what's comfortable for you

The 2 foot rod is the handle of the hammer. You can either use a 3/4" wooden dowel, or you can go full out and use a metal rod or pipe

The two shorter dowels are for attaching Hammer.stl and Pick.stl onto the sides of Main_Body.stl

These can be glued in place with superglue. The two shorter dowels are for attaching Hammer.stl and Pick.stl onto the sides of Main_Body.stl

Aegis-Fang

"Aegis-fang (derived from the mythical shield Aegis) is the weapon of Wulfgar. It was forged for him by his adoptive father Bruenor Battlehammer while he was in servitude of the dwarf king. It was Bruenor's finest creation. Its head is made from pure Mithril with a diamond coating magically adhered during the forging and an adamantite shaft. Its head is engraved with the magical inscriptions of Clangeddin, the dwarven god of battle, as well as the symbols of Moradin, the dwarven god of creation, which covers the symbol of Dumathoin, "keeper of secrets under the mountain".

It is a large and heavy, perfectly balanced Dwarven war hammer +5. When thrown at any giant or giant-class monster, that monster is struck dead (although a powerful Frost Giant named Biggrin was able to take the hit, though it gashed the side of his head and dropped the fifteen-foot-tall giant to the floor). Any person not standing over 6'5" and with considerable strength will have a hard time wielding it properly, though even someone of lesser strength can feel the flawless balance. It is magically attuned to Wulfgar and will reappear in his hand upon command.

Wulfgar has been trained extensively by Drizzt Do'Urden with this weapon. He has used it in two battles against dragons, a shadow dragon named Shimmergloom and a white dragon named Icingdeath, both times ending in victory. He also used it in a battle beside Drizzt Do'Urden and Bruenor Battlehammer against the balor, Errtu, again ending in victory for the companions." -Wikipedia

I used a lot of reference images on google to complete the model, especially for the head, neck, torso and leg proportions. This is based on the Ingram from patlabor( the first one), and is no where near perfect, but I can say that this is an admirable effort. there are flaws in the model, like the torso needing to be slimmer below the pectoral region, the head, and the legs in their dimensions. These flaws, however, I cannot fix with 123d design alone due to its horrifying geometry. I need to learn blender to fix these issues, for it has better geometry to deal with this.

description.text:
I needed handles for my sparrows picks. Many suggested Plasti-Dip, but that stuff makes a mess and used to smell horrible. It might not smell any more, but I'm not buying it to find out.

So, like many of my things, necessity is the mother of invention; or creation; or derivation? I don't think I can really take credit for invention or creation (in general) of pick handles. I can, however, take credit for creation of these handles.

If you don't know what these are for you probably don't need them. I don't really expect these to be a big hit in the 3D printing community, but if you find them useful please post a Make or Comment.

Upper Handle

Lower Handle

description.text:
This is a remix of the Pi Box found on the
Piclop Laser Scanner by FaanP.

I had many issues printing the original box due to lots of overhangs and very thin wall sections. The remixed box has walls that are twice as thick, as well as a lid that hinges (use small bolts and washers).

Ignore the chunky bits on my printed model - I went crazy with massive supports after getting so frustrated on the original box, and I set the print distance too close so it turned out terrible.

Supports will need to be on, particularly to support the Pi mounts. The arches can be cut out if they print wrong.

EDITS: Was tested with a PI 2B. SD card slot was moved 0.5mm and extra depth was given to the mounting holes for the Pi. Aside from that, this project is now complete.

Hi, I am designing a 3d printer for a print volume of about 2 to 3 inches ^3. I will attempt to organize and fix the files as the design evolves. However, for now, it is a 'scrapbot' and i am scavenging parts as I find them at the hardware store and in shop. The main frame of the printer is from Miguel's ewaste printer from the site wevolver.com. Maybe I will make kits and start a kickstarter, but for now have fun modding and making a little 3d printer with hardware store parts! I will work on a bill of materials as well for the assembly. I have a working x axis so far and am designing the y and z currently.

description.text:

author: cj1556

print_settings.Notes:: As is, the mask is sized to fit my 10 year old daughter; you may need to (consistently) re-scale all parts in your slicer depending on your needs.

description.text: Whimsical skull mask, inspired by 'Papyrus' from the video game Undertale. Printable by mere mortals, in less than a day! Made so you can both scale and thermoform the completed print for a perfect fit. I also broke down the model into 4 parts so you can print on smaller beds, (optionally) make the mouth move, and position the eyebrows to your liking.

Printer:

Mankati Fullscale XT Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:
  • As is, the mask is sized to fit my 10 year old daughter; you may need to (consistently) re-scale all parts in your slicer depending on your needs.
  • You will need to print two eyebrows; use the 'mirror' function in your slicer to create both the left and right brows.
  • Use PLA so that you can thermoform your finished parts (more on that below)
  • I found this works best if you print with 3 perimeters, especially for the Jaw where you will need the extra strength.
  • Use the default part orientation in the STL files; I spent some time experimenting with different rotations and layouts, and think I found where the models will print the best with the least amount of support material.
  • Don't use rafts - especially on the head and face pieces - since you will gluing them together using the bed-facing surfaces of both parts (both sides should be nice and flat, and join together with little or no seam).
  • Use a brim if you are having bed adhesion issues.

Making the printed parts into a Mask

You will need:

  • Painters tape
  • Super Glue
  • Hot glue gun
  • Thick Rubber gloves (to wear when thermoforming)
    Optionally:
  • Velcro Straps (to hold it the mask on your head)
  • Black '2nd Skin' Mask (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00BF51RS8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) to wear under the Papyrus mask.
  1. Using the Super Glue, glue the 'head' to the 'face' by joining the smooth edges of both parts that were touching the printer bed. I used painters tape to temporarily hold the pieces in alignment while I glued the parts together.
  2. (Optionally) Thermoform the head and jaw pieces. This article will give you an idea of what's involved: http://www.instructables.com/id/Thermoforming-3D-Printed-PLA-for-Use-in-Prostethic/ . I prefer using the hot (near boiling) water approach, where you immerse the part for a few seconds, then slowly mold the pieces into the shape you need. You can do this to the same part/part area over and over till you get it just right. WEAR THICK KITCHEN RUBBER GLOVES TO PROTECT YOUR HANDS!!!!!
  3. Attach the 'jaw' to the 'face' flanges. You can either hot glue the jaw to the face, or attach it loosely (so it still moves) by drilling holes through both parts and attaching with string. If you want the mouth to move when you talk, you can hot glue a piece of foam rubber on the inside of the jaw (under the chin) so it rests against your own chin when your wearing the mask. Another option (that is pictured above) is to use self adhesive velcro squares to attach the jaw to the head... This makes the jaw pose-able at different angles, changing the expression on the mask.
  4. Hot glue the velcro straps on either side of the mask so the ends join/stick around the back of your head (see picture).
  5. Thermoform the eyebrows so they hug the face in the position you desire. Super Glue them into place.
    • If you decide you want to paint your mask, I highly recommend that you hit it with a couple of layers of automotive primer first and lightly sand. Not only will this get rid of the layer lines on your print, but it will also allow your paint to take much better and smoother than on a naked print.
    • Although it makes it a bit more difficult to see, wearing a Black '2nd Skin' Mask under your printed mask makes for a really neat hollow effect, especially when your indoors, and not in bright light (my daughter is wearing one in the picture above).

print_settings.Notes:: The gear ratios get bigger when the sun gear gets smaller, but then the drive shaft also shrinks. At some point the plastic is too thin and weak to drive the output. I've pushed the design almost to the limit of thin drive shafts. The 1:5.33 design uses #6-32 (M4) drive shaft in a 2"(51.7mm) gearbox, and the 2nd design achieves 1:9.8 with #4-40(M3) drive shafts in a 3" (77.4mm) gearbox. I haven't printed the 2nd design yet to see if it can handle the higher torque, but the first design is a bit overbuilt (15mm high) for the light mirrors in our lab.

remixed_from.author: BigFrame
remixed_from.title: My Customized Captive Planetary Gear Set: parametric.

title: Planet Gearbox for Fine Mirror Adjust, parametric

description.text:
Version 1.1
Adjusting mirrors or beamsplitters on an optics bench can be difficult. This device sits between the mirror and the mounting post, and enables fine adjustments with a 5.33:1 gear ratio, so 10 degrees on the dial results in 2 degrees of mirror motion.

The gearbox is made up of 5 parts: a captured planetary gear system (with herringbone teeth); a dial; a planet-gear carrier; a mounting post holder; and a threaded connector ring. The entire set is printed at once, and then assembled. The connector ring holds the carrier between the gearbox and the post-holder. See the exploded picture.

The files are completely parametric, so using OpenSCAD, you can make (almost) any gear ratio you want. I've included two STL files: a 2" diameter 1:5.33 gear box, and a 3" 1:9.8 gearbox, though I haven't yet printed the 2nd version to see how strong it is.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

normal

Infill:

20

Notes:

Because the threads require many facets, they slow down (or crash) the OpenSCAD rendering on my machine. There is an option in the Customizer to put in "fake threads" or disks to get rapid viewing, but prints ought to be done from "real threads".

PLA was used for all the pieces. But I've been getting a lot of snapped posts on the carrier.
I upped the wall thickness to 1.2mm in Cura, because otherwise the thin posts were hollow and too weak. Despite selecting a #6-32 bolt-hole for the central shaft, trying to put a #6-32 into it caused the post to shatter. I've been making do with a #4-40. Whatever you try, just don't force it--the printed posts aren't as strong as extruded plastic pieces.

I fixed the Customizer interface, but found that it still took too much processing for the cloud server to finish. You're probably better off downloading the .scad file yourself and installing OpenSCAD to run it.

The gear ratios get bigger when the sun gear gets smaller, but then the drive shaft also shrinks. At some point the plastic is too thin and weak to drive the output. I've pushed the design almost to the limit of thin drive shafts. The 1:5.33 design uses #6-32 (M4) drive shaft in a 2"(51.7mm) gearbox, and the 2nd design achieves 1:9.8 with #4-40(M3) drive shafts in a 3" (77.4mm) gearbox. I haven't printed the 2nd design yet to see if it can handle the higher torque, but the first design is a bit overbuilt (15mm high) for the light mirrors in our lab.

Cleanup & Assembly

Threads have to be cleaned well.

The side of the gearbox with the Sun gear protruding for the dial is the top.

Breaking the gear loose simply required snapping the dial onto the Sun gear (logo facing out) and twisting.

Excess flashing appeared in one spot on the herringbone teeth on my first print only.This made one spot on the dial rotation very stiff. A penknife was needed to clean that gear (difficult to get access) but 5 minutes of work and the action was very smooth. The 2nd and 3rd prints with different filament didn't have the flashing and rotated right off the glass, even with 0.1mm tolerances.

The Planet-carrier is inserted into the bottom. I had to sandpaper the 5 posts to get them to slide in smoothly--lots of flashing left on my print. Do this gently, I destroyed about 3 carriers (then upped the wall thickness to 1.5mm to get solid, not-hollow, posts).

The connector is threaded onto the gearbox to cover the threads.

The post-holder is then threaded into the connector to hold the Planet-carrier in place.

That's it!

OPTIONAL Metal Hardware

I have included 3 optional metal bolts and 1 nut (colored pink in OpenSCAD view):
1)The post-holder has a set-screw and nut for tightening it up on the post. #4-40 (M3) with nut work nicely,
2)The output shaft has a threaded hole for bolting on the mirror/beam-splitter optics equipment.
3) The Planet-carrier has a threaded hole for a #4-40 (or tinier!) woodscrew that can provide a low-friction pivot up against the post-holder it it needs to be screwed on more tightly. I've been backing off a quarter turn on the post-holder assembly and that seems to make the friction tolerable without a pivot.

Planetary gear design

There are 3 gears in a planetary gearbox: Sun, Planets (riding on a carrier), and Ring. Any one of them can be held fixed, and the other two become an input/output pair. This provides no less than 6 gear ratios. If two gears are fixed, then the system behaves as a 1:1 (a feature used in automatic transmissions).

Formulas for teeth and gear ratios can be derived by considering the ratios of circumferences of the gears or downloaded from the internet--they are also displayed in the OpenSCAD program. The biggest gear ratio is obtained when the Ring is fixed, the Sun is input, and the Planet-carrier is output.

However, the Planets are in-between the Sun and Ring. So to make this accessible, the carrier has an output shaft that comes up through the Sun gear. This shaft is threaded for a bolt that attaches to the optics mirror/beam-splitter. But since most designs drive the Sun gear with an interior shaft, I had to use a sun driver on the outside of the Sun gear teeth, which is where the dial snaps on.

To keep the carrier friction low, I made the Planet-carrier posts as skinny as possible, and put 1mm friction rings (bearings) on the bottom of the posts. In operation the carrier is held in place by being sandwiched between the post-holder and the gearbox.

At larger gear ratios, the Sun gear shrinks, making the output shaft very skinny. Using the 2" (51.7mm) gearbox diameter, I was able to get a 3.7:1 ratio using a 1/4-20 (M6) bolt, a 5.33:1 ratio using a #6-32 (M4) bolt, and a 6:1 ratio using a #4-40 (M3) bolt. For the smaller bolts, I also had to reduce the number of Planets from 5 to 4 to 3, otherwise the planet teeth overlapped. I've also made a 3" gearbox with #4-40(M3) bolt that achieved 1:9.8 for all you extreme gearheads out there. Larger diameter gear boxes should be able to get even higher gear ratios. If higher gear ratios are needed a 2nd set of gears will be needed, this design uses only one planetary gear set.

10/22/2016 Added a 1:9.8 gear ratio, 3" (77.4mm) gearbox, which pushes the limit of torque possible with thin PLA shafts.

The connecter ring now has 10-deg tick marks for helping align, and the logo scales with size.

10/21/2016 Fixed some bugs in the .scad file, now it displays "fake threads" correctly, and warns not to print. If unintentionally printed, however, the parts may still be assembled.

description.text:
I have a small arsenal of C02 and spring-piston BB and pellet guns. I store all of them in a single rifle case. However, I didn't have a good way to store 12 gram CO2 cartridges in the case without them rolling around. This design lets you easily store 5 or 10 cartridges in a flat package.

The 10-cartridge model is suitable for printing on any printer with a bed length of 220-230mm or more. If you have a smaller printer, you'll want to go with the 5 cartridge model instead.

description.text:
Here it is! I hope you enjoy!
This is my very first published creation on Thingiverse, a complete and hopefully useful set of Hiro's armor from Disney's Big Hero.

For this contest I really really put my hardest into the time and effort toward this project. if it doesn't win I completely understand, it has its flaws, some major some minor. But while I sat here and worked on this project for the month I was given in my school's computer lab alongside many others who use the printers we have at school, I realized very shortly that I was not going to be able to print out each design for each piece of the suit, which sucks for me because I know the print quality is a big part of it. Unfortunately the only prints I got were errors in my sizing so... I realize you may need to adjust these pieces to your body and figure, trust me, I have quite a few parts I printed that I cant use ._. But! With that being said, now for the details.

~Recommended settings!~

Helmet                                                4 Files total - 1 Full helmet, 2 halves w/o fins, 1 Fin
    Raft - on     Supports - on

Shoulder                                             1 File (Print 2 of these)
    Raft - on     Supports - on

Chest Pieces                                      4 Files Total                                  
    Raft - on     Supports - on                   - 1 Full Chest, 1 Lower, 1 Upper and 1 base plate

Back Pieces                                       3 Files Total 
    Raft - on     Supports - on                   - 1 Full Back, 1 back piece, and 1 base plate

Glove parts                                         8 Files Total 
    Raft - on     Supports - on                   - Woah ok so print (5) finger 3's, (5) knuckles, 
                                                             (5) finger 2's, (3) glove pad 1's, and (1) glove belt

                  ^ [all of this is for one glove, so if you need to make two do the math] ^
           ^ [By the way you will need a type of base glove, all this is, is padding and junk] ^

Knee pads                                         1 File (Print 2 of these) 
    Raft - on     Supports - on

Shoes                                                2 Files Left and Right 
    Raft - on     Supports - on            (Probably need adjusting to your foot or shoe size)

Printer - MakerBot Replicator 5th Generation
MakerBot Replicator Z18

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Yes

Yes

Notes:

For the helmet i actually used the MakerBot Replicator Z18.

My girlfriend and i had been to a covention locally just this past year and she of course had gone as Hiro, from big hero 6 but in his normal attire. As im sitting around trying to think of some kind of costume to make i get a notification from Facebook in which my gf actually has her profile as her picture from last year's con. So after finally coming up with the idea to make his armor, i run it by her to see what she thinks. Lets just say she nearly knocked me over with excitement. So there you have it.

Hope you enjoy it.

Hover boards, or balance scooters, seemed to home and go with a "bang." However, I think the newer, safer versions out now provide a great opportunity for those with limited mobility. An electric wheel chair or scooter can cost thousands of dollars, which is especially difficult for those on a limited, fixed income.

Enter the Handi Hover Mobility Bracket.

Once printed (I suggest ABS or PETG at 100% infill for strength) a 5/16" x 2" hex bolt is inserted through the hole, and felt tape is applied to the inside of the bracket. The bracket is secured to the center of a standard hover board using 3" pipe clamps.

The front casters are removed from the wheelchair (this one was $20 at the Salvation Army) and extra brackets added. The foremost bracket is attached to the Handi Hover Bracket with a few washers and a wingnut using thread lock.

All that the rider does is sits, and positions the feet on the pads of the balance scooter to propel themselves. Minimal strength of the feet/lower legs is required, and even a child can ride it.

Warning** A standard wheel chair is inherently top-heavy, and at max hover board speeds is likely to tip if you corner too quiclky (ask me how I know...) I would suggest that if your hoverboard is beeping, you are going WAY TOO FAST! There are some balance scooters that have the ability to limit speeds... it might be best to use one of those if you are worried about the rider going too fast.

---This is a NON-COMMERCIAL endeavor that is in development. It is NOT appropriate to use this bracket, or any derivative of it, for commercial purposes.---

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jBwdocihJHw

This bracket could also be used to connect a hand truck or a wagon to your hover board, to drag along your stuff as you go...

/* Controle automático de persianas tipo RollOn

  • . : a e r o n a v i l l e s : .
  • By [email protected]
  • baseado no motor redutor [email protected]:
  • http://www.banggood.com/12V-6rpm-Reversible-High-torque-Turbo-Worm-Geared-Motor-DC-motor-GW370-p-1046052.html
  • 3Dprint box && gear:
  • 123Design: aeronavilles
  • thingiverse: aeronavilles

  • [email protected]

    Funcionamento:
    √ Havendo luz natural as cortinas (RollOn) permanecem abertas;
    √ Ao entardecer as cortinas (RollOn) abaixam automaticamente (~2min);
    √ Ao amanhecer as cortinas (RollOn) sobem automaticamente (~2min);
    √ Pode funcionar como servo-motor de um sistema automatizado;
    √ Botões de subida "UP" e descida "DOWN" manualmente das cortinas para um suave ajuste (OBS: fica nesta posição temporária por 10 x o tempo de ajuste - ou seja, se sua cortina fecha completamente em 2min, então o ajuste temporário é de 20min);
    √ Antes de se ligar o RollOn deve-se baixar completamente as cortinas e fixá-lo em seu lugar, tomando-se o cuidado para encaixar o puxador do lado "baixar" no sentido horário do motor redutor;
    √ Ao se aplicar energia (ligar) o sistema entra em modo de aprendizado:
    √ Verifica os botões "UP" && "DOWN" (por ≈2s) - pressionando brevemente para saber se funcionam adequadamente;
    √ Verifica o nível de luz ambiente (por ≈2s) - basta tampar o sensor para verificar sua operacionabilidade - o LED deve flutuar seu brilho;
    √ A seguir deve-se pressionar e manter pressionado o botão "UP" até que as cortinas estejam em sua posição totalmente abertas - pode-se abaixar momentaneamente através do botão "DOWN" para um melhor ajuste;
    √ Aguarde ≈10s sem pressionar qualquer botão para sair do modo aprendizado (ou por 'default' sai automaticamente em ≈3min);
    √ Se por acaso ignorou o modo aprendizado, então o tempo de subir e descer as cortinas ficam em aproximadamente 1min;
    √ OBS": RollOn ainda em desenvolvimento - utilize por sua conta e risco! (Eu agarantcho!! :)

    /
    /     Automatic Roll On type curtain

  • . : a e r o n a v i l l e s : .
  • By [email protected]
  • based upon motor worm [email protected]:
  • http://www.banggood.com/12V-6rpm-Reversible-High-torque-Turbo-Worm-Geared-Motor-DC-motor-GW370-p-1046052.html
  • 3Dprint box && gear:
  • 123Design: aeronavilles
  • thingiverse: aeronavilles

  • [email protected]

    How it works:
    √ On natural light curtain remain opened (RollOn Up);
    √ At sunset curtain (RollOn) gets down (~2min);
    √ At sunrise curtain (RollOn) opens automatically (~2min);
    √ Ready made servo-assisted from an existing automated roll on system - or none at all;
    √ "UP" && "DOWN" manual button for smooth curtains adjust (OBS: stays on that position for approx. 10 x TEMPO, then returns back to auto - i.e. if TEMPO is 2min then temporary is 20min.);
    √ Before you turns it on curtains must be in DOWN position && fix RollOn on it's position with velcro or other means, taking care of DOWN is motor clockwise;
    √ As you turn it on (ON) system enters 'learning mode':
    √ Check "UP" && "DOWN" buttons (≈2s) - press it briefly to verify it is working for good;
    √ Check light level (≈2s) - just tap it down to see LED changes brightening;
    √ Then press "UP" till totally open curtain position - just press "DOWN" for a better adjust;
    √ Let ≈10s without touch any button to exit 'learning mode' ('default' exits in ≈3min);
    √ If you miss 'learning mode' then TEMPO ≈1min (up && down curtain time are the same);
    √ OBS": RollOn is still developing - mind your own risk & challenge :)

    */

RollOn automatic drop down type curtain

All I need was an automated rollon type window shades curtain to fulfill our windows @home - so I joined Axis Gear on IG... Well, they are good on design and concept, but they're not cheap and all delay on delivery guided me through another way... They inspired me to go on and explore what I made above.

WARNING: THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS...

The RollOn concept:
√ To be cheap;
√ Should use common components available everywhere;
√ I could print on my own;
√ Should be automatic or servo assisted.

The Idea:
√ Wandering on the internet I found a very simple idea that uses wood and a geared stepper motor, as I used as concern. So I looked around and found some interesting cheap DC motor I could use to pull up or down the curtains as easy and silently as possible;
√ Based on 12V 6rpm Reversible High torque Turbo Worm Geared Motor DC motor GW370 bought by Banggood;
√ The box is based on customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1264391
√ The circuit is based on ATTiny (like Digispark V2);
√ The driver for the motor is DC coupled over a mosfet bridge (could serve as other paralell RollOn boxes);
√ The sensor I used is a simple LDR (light dependent resistor);
√ There's an 'Up' and 'Donw' control buttons - to easy manual mode - even an servo input RC pulse type mode available;
√ I'm still in development of the software - please check later for further news...

BOM:

All material + 3DPrinting should be within ≈US20,00
√ Warm geared DC motor: http://www.banggood.com/12V-6rpm-Reversible-High-torque-Turbo-Worm-Geared-Motor-DC-motor-GW370-p-1046052.html
√ ATTiny85: Google for the best on your local or
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Digispark-compatible-developing-board-ATtiny85-MicroUSB/32733676895.html?spm=2114.01010208.3.20.Bu514N&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_3_10065_10056_10068_10055_10054_10069_10059_10078_10079_10073_10017_10080_10070_10082_10081_421_420_10060_10061_10052_10062_10053_10050_10051,searchweb201603_4&btsid=2404888f-2cc0-4d89-97df-023ea9774aa6 or http://www.banggood.com/ATTINY85-Mini-Usb-MCU-Development-Board-For-Arduino-p-971122.html?rmmds=search
√ 4 Mosfet (or relays): http://www.banggood.com/1-Pc-30A-200V-IRFP250-IRFP250N-IR-Power-N-Channel-MOSFET-Transistor-p-922206.html or http://www.banggood.com/10Pcs-IRFZ44N-Transistor-N-Channel-Rectifier-Power-Mosfet-p-953277.html?rmmds=search or https://www.aliexpress.com/item/10pcs-IRF520-TO220/2030702081.html?spm=2114.01010208.3.1.zvDZma&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_3_10065_10056_10068_10055_10054_10069_10059_10078_10079_10073_10017_10080_10070_10082_10081_421_420_10060_10061_10052_10062_10053_10050_10051,searchweb201603_4&btsid=4f035d10-a146-473a-bb02-9938b8c3944b
√ LDR: http://www.banggood.com/50Pcs-5MM-GL5516-Light-Dependent-Resistor-Photoresistor-LDR-p-943461.html
√ Battery: http://www.banggood.com/2x-Elfeland-3_7V-3000mAh-18650-Li-ion-Battery-EU-US-Plug-Charger-p-1056833.html?rmmds=detail-left-hotproducts or
http://www.banggood.com/10Pcs-USB-Lithium-Battery-Charger-Module-With-Charging-And-Protection-p-943765.html
√ Plus all the basic: cables, wires, solder, pacience, etc =)

UPDATED: 2016/11/04:
√ RollOn_V2.ino is ready (but not servo ready);
√ Added RollOn_V2.fzz (fritzing schematic software) for a better understanding;
√ Using 4 x AA batteries (instead of expensive LiOn batt);
√ Added step-up boost circuit for a better motor stroke && fast response: https://pt.aliexpress.com/item/Cool-XL6009-4A-DC-DC-Step-Up-Voltage-Boost-Power-Supply-Converter-Module-DIY-Free-Shipping/32345682592.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.Kws54b&detailNewVersion=&categoryId=400103

UPDATED: 2016/11/08:
√ Using 4x1.5V alcaline batteries will endure for ≈20hrs on this duty-cycle (≈4 min/day) - so I modify the inverter to function just when needed (≈50mA economy!), by enabling it's EN pin based on digispark's LED pin - so, quiescent current will be around 20mA - just not enough, but OK for now ;)

UPDATED: 2016/11/10:
√ It could be also used NiCd cells instead of alcaline batteries + solar cells for longer periods - use this:
√ https://pt.aliexpress.com/item/Portable-Solor-Charger-10000mAh-Waterproof-Solar-Mobile-Phone-PowerBank-For-Samsung-Universal-Battery-Backup/32616435976.html?spm=2114.10010308.1000015.27.UgcLCT&s=p&detailNewVersion=&categoryId=200002222 or that:
√ http://www.banggood.com/20000mAh-External-Solar-Power-Bank-Battery-Charger-Dual-USB-With-Charging-Cable-For-Mobile-Phone-p-1077480.html?rmmds=search
√ Remake of the .stl to add power button, LED && LDR outside the box, buttons "UP" && "DOWN" (just under the logo);
√ 123dx file exploded view to explain where I did put all components;

comments.text:
Hi Andreas,
This is a work in progress - RollOn V3 is running since October/2017 and as it requires lots of torque to get my rollon up little noisy is expected, but Ok for me!
The files are downloadable on this thing zip side (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1838727/zip) - the .ino and all files' also reachable at my drive:
https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0BwmMaG0yXo-DOXA5MHpNc0I2VUU?usp=sharing
I have only one unit working for previewing failures, as i'm still waiting for my indiegogo's Axis Gear system to integrate the other 12 curtains I intent to iterate with...
It is a good Idea of yours eliminating the prescaling circuit voltage, but I'm comfortable to fine tuning the voltage to generate enough torque on this not so bad worm gear I choose. Don't forget to put some LiOn batt protection circuit to provide safe amperage on your project if you intend to use it as master battery - my choices still cheap 4 NiCad and an external 5V USB eliminator power source from previous projects (Apple old 5V USB pug works as well), when I have access to solar cells I'll check on Lithium too :)
Spare time to post some video is my gap at this time... I'll try my best!
Tks and keep the good faith!

comments.text:
Hi David,
This is a work in progress on the awaiting hours of receiving my perk on Indiegogo (Axis Gear) - that complete my set of curtains/rollon automatic Up/Down type.
As you can see on the 5th. 3D picture all the electronics fit on the front of the gear motor - opposed as the battery place. It's based on the tiny Digispark module that controls a worm reduction motor - it opens at sunrise and go down on dusk time. You can bring it Up or Down with the buttons as you wish to take a quick look outside, for instance (I inserted 2 micro pushbuttons on my logo's dots "." that floors out of the case for ease access...).
The program part of the Digispark module carefully explains that - when you manually press the Up/Down buttons the curtains/rollon stays by the attitude you choose for some minutes then it automatically close or open by the meanings of the sunlight (let's say if you program to bring curtains UP is about ~1.5 min => Then 1.5 min * 10 = 15 min as "standby" hold time).
Several iterations on the making of the spoke gears bring me the "RollOn_20_spoke_gear_V5" that I'm using at the moment.
I've got to use a DC booster to bring the ~5V voltage to at least ~12V for the motors, as using a +5V AC adapter from an old USB port to power the circuit (It's thought to be portable but the rechargeable batteries don't last too long!). The project is fully available @my drive.google (https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0BwmMaG0yXo-DOXA5MHpNc0I2VUU?usp=sharing).
When I have some spare time I'll post a video of the functioning hours of it (sunrise to sunset).
Please feel free to modify as your wish - the ESP8266 was on my first choice - maybe when I got the Indiegogo's Axis Gear perks installed I'll put them to work with/or an Alexa to manage it as well...
If you're lucky with these devices to work together please share your discoveries!
Best &&
Fabio Romano,
.:aeronavilles:.
